author: Nigel Thompson
title: Brits heading to Canada next year are off to a flying start for savings with wave of new routes
text:
​Brits heading to Canada next summer are off to a flying start for savings with a wave of new routes as carriers battle for business.
Budget airline WestJet, which already flies from Glasgow, starts from Gatwick in spring at £163 one-way.
From May 6 it will offer direct services to Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Winnipeg, Toronto and St John's, with introductory £10 fares on connecting flights to selected cities.
They will be flying the Boeing 767-300 ER except on the shorter St John's route, which will use a smaller Boeing Next-Generation 737-700. Both aircraft have premium and economy cabins with a new inflight entertainment system and wi-fi, including power at every seat. westjet.com
Canada fly: travellers from Glasgow airport can head to Montreal in Quebec from May 30
Rival carrier Air Canada will start a seasonal service with its leisure airline, called rouge, from Glasgow to Toronto. From June 14 the route will be operated by Boeing 767-300ER aircraft, also with a choice of cabins and inflight entertainment streamed to personal electronic devices.
Fares start at £401 return with flights timed to connect with Air Canada's network across the Americas. aircanada.com
Also entering the UK-Canada summer fray is leisure airline Air Transat, which starts a Glasgow-Montreal route from May 30 in addition to its seasonal schedule which offers Gatwick to Toronto, Vancouver , Calgary and Montreal; Glasgow and Manchester to Toronto, Vancouver and Calgary; and Birmingham to Toronto.
The airline also offers two cabins plus touch screens with on-demand entertainment on its Airbus A330 fleet. Return fares to Quebec City start at £385. airtransat.co.uk
BA unveils first refurbished jumbo The first of 18 British Airways’ refurbished Boeing 747 jumbo jets has gone into service.
The revamped planes get a Panasonic next generation eX3 in-flight entertainment system with a tablet feel and upgraded seats with power, bringing the 747s more in line with BA’s new Dreamliners and A380 superjumbos. ba.com
